awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Directing the Reactivity of Cyclometalated Complexes in Late Transition Metal-Based Homogeneous Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Pinjing Zhao of North Dakota State University Fargo is studying metal-based catalysts for the synthesis of organic molecules. Metal catalysts, molecules that speed up reactions, must interact with the target starting materials (substrates) in order to transform the reactants into products. Dr. Zhao is studying the rational design and development of new catalysts, including those that do not employ expensive and rare metals, to provide new tools for environmentally-friendly chemical synthesis. This project provides interdisciplinary research training and career preparation for graduate and undergraduate students. Catalytic and synthetic reactions are introduced in the sophomore organic chemistry lecture course. Student projects are developed for the inorganic laboratory course to provide hands-on experience with instrumentation and lab techniques. Professor Zhao leads the construction of a web-based database to promote general dissemination of the fundamental knowledge and recent research progress on organometallic chemistry. This database provides valuable training experiences for graduate and undergraduate students training them for careers in industry, government and academia. 

Dr. Zhao is developing catalytic applications of late transition metal-based cyclometalation processes. Catalytically-relevant metallacycles are generated through nickel- and ruthenium-mediated C-H bond activation of ancillary ligands such as N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) and aromatic N-H ketimines. Other target cyclometalation processes include rhodium- and ruthenium-mediated decarboxylation of arene- and heteroarenecarboxylic acids via chelation assistance. Results of structure-reactivity relationships of cyclometalated catalyst precursors and reactive intermediates are guiding new catalyst developments via atom-efficient activation of strong chemical bonds including carbon-hydrogen, oxygen-hydrogen, and carbon-carbon bonds. Dr. Zhao is also leading an initiative to develop a web-based searchable database to promote general dissemination of fundamental knowledge on chemical bond transformations in organometallic chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The development of highly efficient and selective catalytic reactions via mild activation of inert chemical bonds is a significant task for synthetic chemists. Transition metal-mediated cyclometalation is a powerful strategy for such bond activation processes via chelation assistance. Better understanding of the fundamental reactivity of cyclometalated complexes will provide important guidance to direct their applications as catalyst precursors or reactive intermediates in rational catalyst design and improvement. In current project, we aim to focus on cyclometalation-based catalytic C-H activation and decarboxylation processes that could positively impact eco-friendly chemical synthesis. During this funding period, we have advanced catalyst development and substrate scope evaluation of several catalytic processes involving cyclometalated intermediates via chelation-assisted bond activation processes. These reactions include Ni-catalyzed dehydrogenative alcohol transformations via NHC cyclometalation, Rh- and Ru-catalyzed arene functionalizations via chelation-assisted C-H activation and decarboxylation, and Rh-catalyzed [3+2] annulation process via isocyanate-directed cyclometalation.  

Based on new results obtained with current funding support, we have also carried out mechanism understanding and catalyst development of Ni-catalyzed alkyne hydroamination process as an atom-efficient method for C-N bond formation. We obtained mechanistic results that support a proposed hydroamination pathway via alkyne insertion into Ni-amide linkage. This alkyne hydroamination mechanism is fundamentally different from the typical pathway of alkyne activation with late transition metal catalysts as Lewis acids and draws analogy with early transition metal-catalyzed alkyne hydroamination via amine activation. We envision that such merged traits of early- and late-transition metal catalysis will open up new windows of opportunity for Ni-catalyzed hydroamination and other aminative transformations involving catalytically active Ni amide species. In particular, we have obtained preliminary results as proof-of-concept for Ni-based development of tandem amination transformations towards atom-efficient construction of nitrogen-heterocycles. With the synergy between mechanism study and catalyst development, results from this project are expected to enhance the fundamental knowledge on structure-reactivity correlations in organometallic chemistry.

Broader Impacts

This project has provided full or partial salary support for 2 postdoc associates, 4 graduate students, and 1 short-term visiting scholar for research at the home institution (NDSU). In addition, this project has provided research opportunities for 2 undergraduate students via enrollment in a research course. Participating students have received scientific and research training in multiple areas including organic chemistry, inorganic and organometallic chemistry, homogeneous catalysis, and physical methods for reaction mechanism studies.

Results from this research has been disseminated to the scientific community through 3 invited seminars and 2 conference presentations by the PI and 4 ACS meeting presentations (3 national and 1 regional) by graduate students. Several manuscripts describing results from this study are currently in preparation and will be submitted for publication at peer-reviewed journals. Participation student researchers have gained relevant experience in scientific writing, professional presentations, and interacting with fellow scientists in the community.  

Through continuous participation in various educational and outreach activities, the PI's research group has provided exposure to modern organometallic chemistry and catalysis for REU students, visiting high school students for summer research, as well as high school student parents and science teachers in the local community via the COINS (Career Opportunities In Nature Sciences) outreach program. The PI has also utilized the undergraduate organic chemistry courses as an active platform for teaching innovations and research-related curriculum development.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2022
Modified by: Pinjing Zhao
